Yannick Loiseau wrote:
> 
> I'm modeling a search engine in Rest. Queries are more complex than just a
> list of keywords, and should be represented in xml. So my question is: how
> could I send the query to the server ?
> The obvious solution would be a POST, but as it is a search, GET would be
> more convenient?
> An other solution could be:
>     C: POST http://my.server.com/queries/
>     S: 201 Created
>          Location: http://my.server.com/queries/queries/1234
>     C: GET
> http://my.server.com/results?query=http://my.server.com/queries/queries/1234
>     or even
>     C: GET
> http://some.other-server.org/search?query=http://my.server.com/queries/queri
> es/1234
> but I'd like to avoid to much round trip

I agree that this seems to be too much for simple search engine queries, OTH
I think it is a good idea to create a new resource for the 'information 
retrieval interaction', because it opens up the possibility for more complex
retrieval tasks: You could distribute the URI of that resource to various
'information retrieval systems/agents' that can GET the query parameters from
it and POST the results to it. At any time, you could do a GET on the resource
to see the current 'retrieval state', much like you can GET the state of a
shipping order to track the delivery.

I am curious: How do your queries look like?

Jan
